Award.AwardTitle: GEM Professional Development and Travel Grant to National Conference

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The GEM Consortium has a rich-history in broadening participation among underrepresented graduate students in engineering and other STEM fields. Annually, it offers an abundance of opportunities, where underrepresented graduate students are able to supplement their formal graduate education with meaningful professional development and formal and informal mentorship from engineering and other STEM faculty. This workshop/travel grant proposal focuses on providing underrepresented graduate students with special professional development opportunities at the 40th GEM Conference & Gala. Through these professional development opportunities, underrepresented graduate students will be provided mentorship and other meaningful learning experiences to help them gain greater understanding and preparation for the professoriate in engineering and other STEM fields. Progress in diversifying the ranks of the faculty has been slow in engineering and many other STEM fields. The effort to increase the representation of African Americans, Hispanics, and Native Americans in engineering and other STEM fields is a priority of NSF.

Through a workshop format, this project aims to advance underrepresented graduate students' research knowledge and skills, while exposing them to strong mentorship and support systems in engineering and other STEM fields. The broader significance and importance of this project is its focus on positively influencing the STEM faculty pipeline by equipping underrepresented graduate students with knowledge, skills, and support to successfully pursue careers at the faculty ranks. This project is closely aligned with NSF's strategic goals and priorities to increase the participation of underrepresented groups at all levels of the STEM educational pipeline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goals of GEM Travel Grant Award program are to positively impact the nation’s welfare by increasing the ranks of underrepresented minorities considering careers in the academy.

The program provided participants with travel funds so they could attend the GEM Annual conference and participate in opportunities for professional development focused on how to prepare for faculty careers and network with university and corporate GEM partners. For the first year of this grant efforts were focused on awarding travel grants to GEM Associate Fellows, a group that might not have had funds to travel otherwise to the national conference. In total 27 graduate students who were GEM Associate Fellows participated in the program.

The three day conference with technical sessions allowed graduate students to present their research as well as attend sessions on how to prepare for a faculty career, how to network with industry and university liaisons, and other sessions focused on hearing how others navigated different career paths successfully.

A survey was conducted of all 27 program participants to determine their satisfaction with the professional development activities and gain an understanding of what impact the conference attendance had on their career goals. We plan on conducting additional surveys with program participants who travelled to the 2017 Annual Conference as well. The survey results to date indicate that the conference allowed for networking opportunities that they would not have had otherwise and made participants feel more prepared to pursue a faculty career. Participants noted that they had a better understanding of what future employers look for in their new hires. Respondents also noted that they were receiving support and mentoring from most of their home institutions and would like to continue to receive additional opportunities through GEM.

Results of the survey of the program participants were shared at the following year's annual conference. A group of faculty, university administrators, and GEM industry reps discussed survey results and participated in a session designed to collectively determine what future conferences and professional opportunities were necessary to prepare future STEM leaders.
